thread.title: Jeff Sessions Denies Latest Claim Linking Russia To Trump Campaign
thread.title_full: Jeff Sessions Denies Latest Claim Linking Russia To Trump Campaign

author: Jack Davis
title: Jeff Sessions Denies Latest Claim Linking Russia To Trump Campaign

organizations.name: trump campaign jeff sessions denies latest claim linking russia to trump campaign

text:
Jeff Sessions Denies Latest Claim Linking Russia To Trump Campaign "... the Attorney General must resign ..." by Jack Davis March 2, 2017 at 6:50am Share on Facebook Share Tweet Email Email Print Advertisement - story continues below 
One day after President Donald Trump electrified the nation with a speech that looked like it would turn the corner of his presidency, the White House was rocked again by a new version of an old allegation. 
The Washington Post , citing “Justice Department officials” who were not named, said Attorney General Jeff Sessions met twice with Russian officials during the 2016 campaign, including one September meeting in his office with Russian Ambassador Sergey Kislyak. 
The reports fueled calls for Sessions to recuse himself from any investigation into the Trump campaign’s ties with Russia, which Sessions said he would do, if necessary. Advertisement - story continues below 
— Jason Chaffetz (@jasoninthehouse) March 2, 2017 
The White House , however, said that meeting was being mischaracterized as part of a political witch hunt. 
During his confirmation hearing, Sessions was asked by Sen. Al Franken, D-Minn., about contacts between the Trump campaign and Russia. Advertisement - story continues below 
“I’m not aware of any of those activities,” Sessions said, adding, “I have been called a surrogate at a time or two in that campaign and I did not have communications with the Russians.” 
Sessions and the White House drew a distinction between what Sessions did as a sitting U.S. senator and his role in the Trump campaign. 
On Wednesday night, Sessions released a statement saying he “never met with any Russian officials to discuss issues of the [Trump] campaign. I have no idea what this allegation is about. It is false.” 
On Thursday morning, he told NBC News , “I have not met with any Russians at any time to discuss any political campaign, and those remarks are unbelievable to me and false, and I don’t have anything else to say about that.” Advertisement - story continues below Father Of First SEAL To Die During Trump Administration Demands Investigation 
Neither Sessions nor the White House denied the meeting with Kislyak, but said it had nothing to do with the Trump campaign. 
“There was absolutely nothing misleading about his answer,” said Sarah Isgur Flores, Sessions’ spokeswoman. “He was asked during the hearing about communications between Russia and the Trump campaign – not about meetings he took as a senator and a member of the Armed Services Committee.” 
“This is the latest attack against the Trump Administration by partisan Democrats,” the White House said in a statement. “General Sessions met with the ambassador in an official capacity as a member of the Senate Armed Services Committee, which is entirely consistent with his testimony.” 
The White House noted that the news followed hard on the heels of Trump’s well-received speech to a joint session of Congress 
“lt’s no surprise Senator AI Franken is pushing this story immediately following President Trump’s successful … address to the nation,” the statement said. 
Some Republicans said the latest news means Sessions should recuse himself from any investigation into the Trump’s campaign ties — or lack of them — with Russia. 
“If there is something there, and it goes up the chain of investigation, it is clear to me that Jeff Sessions, who is my dear friend, cannot make this decision about Trump,” said Sen. Lindsey Graham, R-S.C. “So they may be not – there may be nothing there, but if there’s something there if the FBI believes is criminal in nature, then, for sure, you need a special prosecutor. If that day ever comes, I’ll be the first one to say it needs to be somebody other than Jeff.” 
House Minority Leader Nancy Pelosi, D-Calif., had another solution in mind. 
“Jeff Sessions lied under oath during his confirmation hearing before the Senate,” she said. “Now, after lying under oath to Congress about his own communications with the Russians, the Attorney General must resign. Sessions is not fit to serve as the top law enforcement officer of our country and must resign.” What do you think? Scroll down to comment below. Advertisement Popular Right Now
